resources.string: Start with 5–10 minutes of light cardio exercise such as running in place, jumping jacks, marching to warm up your muscles and prepare your body for the workout.
Push–ups: 3 approaches of 10–15 reps. You can start with knees if regular push-ups are difficult.
Pull-ups (if you have a horizontal bar or special stick): 3 approaches for the maximum number of reps, with pauses as needed.
Push–ups on the bars: 3 sets of 10–15 repetitions. If no bars are available, you can use a regular seat.
Squats: 3 sets of 15–20 reps. You can do regular squats or deep squats by shifting your hips back.
Lunges: 3 sets of 12 reps for each leg.
Bridge: 3 approaches of 15 reps. Lie on your back, bend your legs at the knees, and lift your pelvis up while tensing your glutes.
Plank: Hold the plank 3 times for 30 seconds. Gradually increase the time.
Plie squats: 3 sets of 15–20 reps. Spread your feet wider than shoulder width apart, toes slightly apart.
Back Lunges with leg raises: 3 sets of 12 reps for each leg.

Facelift Exercise: Sit up straight, place your fingers on the appropriate areas of your face (cheeks, chin), apply a little resistance as you try to lift the area of skin. Perform 3 approaches for 15 seconds for each area.
End your workout with 5–10 minutes of stretching, focusing on your whole body. Remember proper exercise technique and listen to your body, avoiding pain or overexertion.

This set of exercises covers most of the body and will help maintain overall fitness. It is important to gradually increase the intensity and volume of the workout over time, as well as paying attention to proper nutrition and regular rest.

A personalized meal plan for weight loss should take into account your needs, goals, lifestyle and medical conditions. It is important to create a balanced plan that ensures proper nutrient intake, controls calories, and keeps you fit. Below is a general weight loss meal plan template:
Omelet of two eggs with vegetables (spinach, tomatoes, mushrooms, etc.).
A serving of oatmeal on water or low-fat milk with berries and nuts.
A cup of green tea or coffee without sugar.
Greek yogurt with non-fat toppings (honey, nuts, berries).
Grilled or baked chicken breast with spices.
A serving of quinoa or brown rice.
Fresh vegetable salad with olive oil and lemon juice.
Steamed fish (salmon, cod, tilapia) with seasonings.
Almond butter or olive oil for grilling half a whole wheat flour loaf.
Consume more fruits and vegetables as they are rich in vitamins, minerals and dietary fiber.
Avoid high-calorie drinks, preferring water, low-fat milk, nonfat yogurt.
Limit your intake of fast carbohydrates (sugar, sweets, white bread).
Keep portions reasonable to control the caloric intake of your meals.
Consider your individual activity and body\'s needs.
Include protein in every meal as it will help keep you satiated and maintain muscle mass.

Always consult your doctor or nutritionist before starting any diet or changing your normal eating habits. Individual needs and limitations may vary, and a professional can help tailor a meal plan based on your circumstances.
Losing weight is a process that requires attention to diet, physical activity and lifestyle in general. Here are a few guidelines that can help you achieve your goal:
Determine how much weight you want to lose and over what period of time. Realistic goals will make the weight loss process more achievable and motivating.
Eat a variety of foods rich in vitamins, minerals and nutrients. Favor lean proteins, healthy fats (e.g. olive oil) and complex carbohydrates (whole grain flours, vegetables).
Keep portions moderate to avoid overeating. Use smaller eating utensils - this can help you perceive portions as more filling.
Eat small meals every 3–4 hours. This will help keep your blood sugar levels stable and avoid excessive feelings of hunger.
Drink enough water throughout the day. Water helps keep your metabolism going and reduces appetite.
Incorporate regular exercise into your daily routine. Combine cardio (running, swimming, walking) with strength training. Physical activity helps burn calories and strengthen muscles.
Proper sleep is important for metabolism and overall health. Aim for 7–9 hours of sleep per night.
Keep a food and exercise diary to track your progress and make adjustments to your plan if necessary.
Stress can affect weight and appetite. Practice relaxation techniques such as yoga, meditation or walking outdoors.
Share your goal with loved ones or friends. They can support you during difficult moments and help you stay motivated.
If you have medical concerns or want a customized plan, talk to a nutritionist or trainer.

Remember that weight loss is an individualized process. What works for one person may not work for another. The most important thing is to find an approach that is tailored to your personal characteristics and preferences.
